headline: Good People, but low pay
pros: People are generally nice and caring.
cons: Hardly any pay raise with already low pay, high turn over rate.

headline: A good company to settle down.
pros: Comfortable & flexible. Love my team, but it will depend on which team you join.
cons: Low pay, not too much room for growth. Not to much company benefits, but it's ok.

headline: High Turnover Rate
pros: Great co-workers and people at the company
cons: High turnover rate and very traditional methods of managing

headline: Credit card processing company
pros: Provide services to retails, beauty salon, restaurant

headline: Don't do it
pros: if you really need a job
cons: Bad management, no bonuses, hardly any time off, just bad overall

headline: Great people and culture
pros: Lots of growth opportunities and family like community.
cons: Politics, but who doesn't have that type of issues.

headline: If you do not speak Korean, do not bother
pros: Never fires you because employee turnover rate is huge.
cons: Out of 150 HQ employees almost everyone is Korean except for 1 filipino and 1 mexican.  Without using Korean, communication is just impossible. Employees are heavily cliquey. Unless you are Korean grown up in Korea or Koreatown, you will have to eat your lunch by yourself. Every day is a  just battle here regardless of your title and duties thanks to broken internal processes and bunch of sloppy in-house developed tools that employees themselves don't use fully due to their bad design and utility. Finding a customer's phone number needs at least 3-4 different windows popped open. Office building heavily smells bad. Heaters do not turn on unless its below 45F. Air conditioner do not turn on until interior gets above 85F.  Salaries are well below other company of this size because the merchant processing industry itself do not pay well. If you are one of OG who stayed with CEO Patrick since the beginning of the company when it occupied a corner of a office building on Wilshire blvd in Korea Town  20 years ago then you get decent salary. Any one new should not expect bright future here. If you are a middle aged Korean person with almost no English skill and trying to avoid serving bulgogi at some Korean restaurant then this is your perfect spot. By the way, this company only closes for NYE, X-mas, July 4th, and Labor Day weekend. Some president or famous reverend's birthday? Come to work!

headline: OK for a short time
pros: Work & Life balance
cons:
Very low pay. 
You can't support family.

headline: Not recommended
pros: There are lots of good people.

headline: Executives and Managers
pros: Nice building!!! Nice local area!!! That's all.
cons: Very strict, low wage, no performance evaluation, strong favoritism, no career path, glass ceiling for everything, poor management skills, narrow perspective for human being and employee management. no workplace diversity, poor listening mindset if you are not in one of their favorite group. They don't respect others.

headline: Good environment overall
pros: Supportive, nice culture, with good benefits
cons: Korean-dominated, but nothing much else

headline: Coporate Office in Torrance
pros:
It is a typical Korean-culture company, with full blown American spirit. CEO/Founder is a true proponent of doing it "Korean way", with "American style", if that makes any sense. 

Korean way meant overtime and hard work ethics were encouraged.
American way meant there was 401K, group health insurance, PTOs, etc.
(You get 1 PTO during the month of your Birthday, that you must use up that Month of it expires)
cons: Korean culture can be a con to many. "Clique"-y environment, with a lot of sucking up.

headline: account executive
pros: work at your own pace
cons: you may put in over 40 hours the first few weeks but they will only pay 200.

headline: customer service reps
pros: comfortable ,free lunch breakfast .quite cubical

headline: Highly dissatisfied
pros: There is no pros. I can't think of any really...
cons:
Incompetent, horrible management esp VPs (their only interest is office politics)
HQ's inefficient way of handling and distributing work 
Very high turn over rates of employees <- proving my point 
Below average salary
